topic.title: site data locally stored unencrypted?
topic.body: is this normal? Some sites' data that I'm seeding is not encrypted on my hard drive.

topic.title: WHO OWNS ZERONET?
topic.body:
inb4
># it's decentralised! 

No but I mean, really. At this point... is there anyone who controls it? The trackers for example; if they are shut down, then the whole things fall apart as well? Can someone disconnect the trackers from outside? Can we add trackers to the net, to speed things up? Even if the devs would be ((( coerced ))) to shut it down, would they even be able to do it?

topic.title: Running ZeroNet Overnight Results in System Crash
topic.body: When I leave my Windows 10 running overnight, in the morning I arrive at a black screen. The computer itself is still running but the screen, nor controllers come online. Perhaps it is a Windows setting somewhere that I messed up but I wanted to check first if there's a chance zeronet could have something to do with it.

topic.title: How To Force Stop Updating Sites?
topic.body: So I discovered that if I force help seed an old board, it keeps forever trying to update the site but without success because in the old board there seem to be a lot of 'dead' files. It seems that while zeronet tries to keep updating these thousands of files, it severely slows down the entire system. Can anyone confirm this? If so, how do I stop the updating? I tried deleting the database and rebuild; didn't work.

topic.title: SPARS Plandemic - Jay Dyer's Big Brain, Big Picture Analysis
topic.body:
The [SPARS Plandemic document](https://muddled-vest.surge.sh/) (clearnet) is a pandemic table top exercise published by John Hopkins Institute. The document outlines a pandemic scenario that is eerily close to the real life pandemic. So what's the punch line? It was written in 2017. 
The link will take you to a written summary of this strange document, but more importantly, I would suggest to listen to Jay's analysis.

topic.title: Zer0net NAS
topic.body: Is it possible to run zeronet on a server so that it seeds 24/7? Probably it is.. but how do you transfer the data you browse on your client to the NAS? So that your client doesn't have to run 24/7.

topic.title: Why You Shouldn't Take The Jab
topic.body:
4chan schizos have come up with a plausible hypothesis that formulates a rational argument on why it is unwise to the vaccine at this point. 

> The most severe cases of coof cause inflammation along the JAK-STAT pathway leading to cytokine storm (very similar to AIDS) but luckily JAK inhibitors inhibit this cytokine activity. However there is a hidden catch: the most devastating side effect of JAK inhibitor drugs is… sterility.

> The vaccine offers no protection because the antibodies your body generate in response to its spike proteins have no effect on the actual coof because it mutates constantly. In effect, this makes the vaccine to not only offer protection but very likely makes the disease MUCH worse. 

> The worse the disease gets, the more likely doctors will treat you with JAK-inhibitors which will cause you to go infertile. These JAK-inhibitors are already being used everywhere. 

source: https://disagreeable-eyes.surge.sh/ (clearweb)

1617873274_1Nv7HrYvwPjyGyx6iUG7KZrj4TNdu.body: I feel like everyone knows that we need to establish a global peer 2 peer system. But so far I think what is missing, is some sort of 'standard' protocol so that every bit of P2P tech can be joined. In all honesty I don't know enough of the technical playing field to say something sensible other than FOR FUCK'S SAKE, WHAT'S THE FUCKING HOLD UP YOU GOD DAMN DEVS?

>Will IPFS be the new Zer0net?
I've been checking out IPFS and it works well enough... a big stepping stone to get people to migrate is ease of use and fast loading time. Are there currently public message boards hosted on the IPFS network? 

> [certy](#comment_14_1qNWEDofNoMxA5vQoWoDeC6fZ5Dt6Wgif): it's a war, why are you sooo dumb and guilible and naive
preaching to choir bro; people seem to prefer betting on crypto rather than building servers and applications to help decentralise the web. People seem not to understand this very simple truth: anyone who wants free internet, has to self-host. In stead, they are all betting their money and likely going to lose it all because of a fake bubble so that globo homo banksters can claim full ownership 'to protect' your monies. 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iYn6EQDqTkU

> [certy](#comment_34_1qNWEDofNoMxA5vQoWoDeC6fZ5Dt6Wgif): money has no value in the fields of war... only trust and will. example what was the value of money in the hills of hiwojima?
Exactly. People need to be building servers and connect to the new networks in stead of reading bitcoin maps. Currently all the mass communication platforms are owned by one centralised globo homo and discussing anything that does not comply to their rule gets swept into oblivion. Even on FB it is incredibly obvious how they are shadow banning and compartmentalising people into fragmented echo chambers. Authentic, grassroots resistance is no longer possible. Thus the only logical solution is to set up a decentralised, self-hosted network. The only think globo homo could do is literally coerce governments to shut down the internet; but if they do that, they show their cards and they are fucked. So we need to get people off of orthodox social media and get them on blockchain infrastructure ASAP. All the idiots betting their money are wasting their time and energy all in spite of short-term thirst for quick cash; and even worse: they are actively compromising the true ideology and raisain d'être behind crypto. 
> [certy](#comment_29_1qNWEDofNoMxA5vQoWoDeC6fZ5Dt6Wgif): most coders have a too low awareness of the world around them, they are the perfect tools.
Sad but very true.

> [randname666](#comment_63_1HpSHmnQ3cp4oP3hRQsqr1f4U5T7ZL29zK): Not really a friendly "browser" though. It's more an archival/storage system rather than webpages. Though you can definitely hold webpages in IPFS.

I see. For some weird reason I am more inclined to 'trust' zeronet because it was literally one of the first (if not the very first to create a decent P2P net browsing experience. Therefore I think the owners aren't likely to be pozzed. IPFS however has partnerships with various companies and even chainlink... so I'm not likely to trust that. 
Ultimately we need something no single person or centralised power can stop. Is that a possibility with zeronet? Can the devs still 'stop' this network? Something to do with the BitTorrent trackers maybe? Dunno.

> [akashi](#comment_2_13F2Tpa4B5BT72c2Qg3eSLWsGhjZPiCp2g): The most important is anonymity and uncensibility. What we have now is a crime. An interface has to be found that allows google Zeronet pages to be packed on the server. I've already experimented with IPFS. Pining services are needed to keep the pages online. So the directness is gone. The pining services are also a possibility of censorship. Therefore, IPFS can only be used to a limited extent.

if you 'enable Tor for every connection' apparently your IP *should* be hidden, although I have heard people claim on 4chan that certain intelligence agencies may be able to trace your IP in spite of Tor. Whether or not you use Tor or a VPS, you'll always have to 'trust' someone else to keep your data away from the authorities.

> [6283822](#comment_90_12sCaEUFqE6g3JrDqmEA8pn9yrgxwkZQMe): auto-use filters from trusted parties 

sounds good; take a look here; there are some more ideas being discussed to counter spam and illegal content. The goal is limit (ideally forfeit) centralized power. Using A.I. to combat bots and spam seems like a good idea. 
https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/issues/2746
Also take a look at what this guys said: 
https://boards.4channel.org/g/thread/81133794#p81172364

dunno; newfag here

Yeah I had figured it out, but thx!

> [zeroseed5](#comment_8_1HVwr4J7Hd5iENz5hnBE4z4j1K3L85AAMg): Always spoiler. Dont download anything in auto.(to avoid any legal problem) Increased max filesize. More file formats

to avoid auto download, you never increase the max file size?

> [zeroseed5](#comment_8_1HVwr4J7Hd5iENz5hnBE4z4j1K3L85AAMg): Always spoiler. Dont download anything in auto.(to avoid any legal problem) Increased max filesize. More file formats

to avoid auto download, you never increase the max file size?

> [zeroseed5](#comment_8_1HVwr4J7Hd5iENz5hnBE4z4j1K3L85AAMg): Always spoiler. Dont download anything in auto.(to avoid any legal problem) Increased max filesize. More file formats

to avoid auto download, you never increase the max file size?

> [zeroseed5](#comment_9_1HVwr4J7Hd5iENz5hnBE4z4j1K3L85AAMg): No. I tried to increase max filesize as an indipendent feature 😁 i dont know if worked

oh I think I get it now:
- size limit: limits the amount of data you keep seeding; you seed everything you have ever downloaded, unless you remove it
- download and help seed all files: overwrites size limit and downloads all files when they become available and seeds them
- auto download max file size: specifies a data limit for each individual file

1618137037_1HVwr4J7Hd5iENz5hnBE4z4j1K3L8.body: So you're going to post a centralised blocklist others can simply copy paste into their own blocklist?

> [styromaniac](#comment_3067_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRFtVBhd): The comment below yours links to the blocklist.

pretty cool; I love this concept of self-moderation: people are responsible for what they watch and share. Inherently P2P hosting automatically favours content that is popular because more people watch/seed it. It's a bit like the concept of bumping a thread. I love it. I believe in decentralised, P2P networking. I just can't fathom it hasn't taken off yet because normie web is now 99,99% compromised. The time to migrate here is now. Communicating like this is pretty on point. I guess maybe perhaps the zeronet app could be improved upon a little bit but I love how well it works even now.

> [seidoken](#comment_12_1Pxg9q2iUdQkbwgT459ArjQ12mpXN8cyEB): I think alot of these guys are using cp to try and shut down sites and scare off the user base. They might even work for the government of various countries to do it.

yeah this is the rumour going around everywhere, especially on 4chan. It makes sense though; imagine thousands of people start flooding into this place... they will never ever be able to stop it. There is no company to coerce to block their customer from using their hosting services. There is no site owner to pay off. There are no janitors nor moderators. It's all about self-moderation and self-responsibility. I can't get over how genius this is.

> [seidoken](#comment_13_1Pxg9q2iUdQkbwgT459ArjQ12mpXN8cyEB): Yeah I was kind of embarrassed when I found out that this thing that I have been looking for for years has existed for years but it took 8chan getting taken down for me to find it.

Ha! Same here bro. 4chan has become so unusable that I had to search for an alternative. Then I found an [article](https://oilab.eu/infinitys-abyss-an-overview-of-8chan/) about 8chan culture. Here it was mentioned that there had been a P2P backup version made on Zeronet. 
Also; here is screencap of me getting banned for making a thread about [decentralisation](http://127.0.0.1:43110/millchan.bit/data/users/17eJNvVd2HYZVkdwQJuUg1DS6FMknpks1H/src/2392e90cf9ab7edad9d3377791ed960f066b3844.jpg). Another clear sign that they do not want us to organise somewhere they can't control us.

> [transcoder](#comment_27_15q24B3R72uWT1UwtRMdFDmm3VXKcKVSiH): it seems the reason likely comes down to a mix of probably censorship from eastern countries

technically, how would they even go about this? How does an ISP block anything? There is no centralised server and/or domain. Perhaps I'm too much a technical retard but to me it seems that the point of this thing was to have something you can't really shut down as long as there are individuals running zeronet on their machines. The same principle with torrenting. The reason why they have never been able to stop torrenting is because it is P2P. You would have to block literal millions of users. However, what they did do and still do is blocking the websites that host the torrent catalogues. Why? Because it's more realistic to shut down. It's literally the only thing they can do. 
And the same thing applies to zeronet. If they want to shut it down, they would have to shut down the zeronet website and github so that you cannot download any new instances of the code. But then all you would have to do is find mirrors or contact individuals who have backed up the code. 
I have a backup... if they ever shut it down, I'll instantly mirror it on some shady, free file serving service, encrypt it and shill the link/pw in places where ppl might be interested in running zeronet. 
In theory, zeronet should be more resilient than even the Tor network. Why? Because to host a Tor site, you're still using one hosting service. The moment they take this one server down, the site doesn't exist anymore. This is not the case with zeronet: they can seize someone's computer, but the network will still be there.
